deliberation: I checked for metaphors, similes, personification, idioms, and metonymy. The violence described (falling by the sword, infants dashed, pregnant women ripped) is likely literal ANE war-language, not hyperbole by default. The main figurative features are (1) "Samaria" as the city standing for the whole kingdom/people, and (2) the idiomatic expression "fall by the sword," where "sword" stands metonymically for violent military death.

instances.english_text: Samaria must bear her guilt, for she has defied her God.
target: the inhabitants/kingdom of Samaria (the northern Israelite polity)
collective people represented by their capital
vehicle: the city of Samaria as a place-name
capital city standing for its population and regime
ground: the capital embodies and represents the whole kingdom
association of a place with the people who live and rule there
conceptual mapping: place ↔ people
posture: judicial accusation against the northern kingdom
instances.explanation: The name "Samaria" does not refer merely to the physical city but metonymically to the entire northern kingdom and its people, who are said to have rebelled against God.

instances.english_text: They shall fall by the sword
target: the people of Samaria being killed in war
vehicle: death in battle by a weapon
ground: being struck down and losing life through armed conflict
the sword as an emblem of warfare and execution
conceptual mapping: weapon ↔ violent death
instances.explanation: The idiom "fall by the sword" uses "sword" metonymically for warfare and execution, and "fall" metaphorically for being killed, forming a conventional expression for violent military death.

deliberation: I examined the imperatives and causal clause. "Return to YHWH" uses physical movement as a metaphor for repentance/relational restoration. "You have stumbled because of your iniquity" uses bodily stumbling as a metaphor for moral/spiritual failure. Both are standard Hoseanic metaphors.

instances.english_text: Return, O Israel, to the ETERNAL your God
target: Israel’s covenant relationship and obedience toward God
vehicle: physically returning to a person or place
reversal of direction and coming back to a prior location
ground: both repentance and physical return involve turning back from a wrong path to a rightful place
image of restoring broken relationship as going back to someone
conceptual mapping: spatial return ↔ relational/moral return
posture: invitation to restoration rather than mere condemnation
instances.explanation: The verb "return" is not about literal travel but about turning back to God in covenant faithfulness; physical movement is used metaphorically for spiritual and relational restoration.

instances.english_text: For you have fallen/stumbled because of your sin
vehicle: loss of physical balance resulting in a fall
ground: sin disrupts stability and leads to ruin, like an obstacle causing a person to trip
both stumbling and sin-induced failure involve loss of security and forward progress
conceptual mapping: physical stumbling ↔ moral/spiritual collapse
posture: explaining calamity as morally caused rather than accidental
instances.explanation: Israel’s sin is portrayed as an obstacle that causes them to stumble and fall, using the physical experience of tripping as a metaphor for spiritual and national collapse.

deliberation: I looked at "take words," "return," and especially "we will pay bulls [of] our lips." The verse frames speech as something carried and offered like sacrifice. There are two distinct but related metaphors: (1) "take words" treating words as portable objects, and (2) "pay the bulls of our lips" equating verbal confession/praise with sacrificial animals.

instances.english_text: Take words with you and return to GOD
target: Israel’s act of repentance and prayer
verbal confession as an approach to God
vehicle: carrying physical objects on a journey to present them
portable items brought as an offering or gift
ground: words are treated as if they were tangible offerings to be brought before God
both offerings and words are deliberately prepared and presented
conceptual mapping: verbal confession ↔ carried sacrificial gift
posture: instruction in how to repent properly
emphasis on sincere speech rather than mere ritual
instances.explanation: The prophet pictures Israelites "taking" words as if they were physical items to bring on the journey back to God, metaphorically framing confession as a carried offering.

instances.english_text: Instead of bulls we will pay [the offering of] our lips / we will pay the bulls of our lips
target: Israel’s prayers, confessions, and words of praise
vehicle: costly animals surrendered at the altar
ground: both sacrificial bulls and sincere words are costly offerings given to God in worship
speech, like sacrifice, is presented and "paid" to restore relationship
conceptual mapping: lips’ offerings ↔ sacrificial animals
posture: reorientation from external ritual to heartfelt worship
valuing confession and praise over mere animal sacrifice
instances.explanation: The phrase equates the offerings of the lips—prayer and praise—with bulls given in sacrifice, treating verbal worship as a sacrificial payment to God.

deliberation: I considered whether "Assyria shall not save us" or "ride on horses" are figurative; they are mainly literal references to political-military reliance. The clearly figurative expression is "the work of our hands" used for idols, a metonymy where what is produced stands for the cult objects themselves.

instances.english_text: Nor ever again will we call our handiwork our god
target: the idols Israel has made and worshiped
man-made cult objects treated as deities
ground: idols are in fact human artifacts, the result of their handiwork
focusing on their manufactured origin exposes the folly of calling them "our god"
conceptual mapping: manufactured object ↔ idol
posture: repudiation of idolatry and self-made deities
instances.explanation: The phrase "work of our hands" stands metonymically for the idols themselves, highlighting that what they have worshiped as gods are merely human-crafted objects.

deliberation: I looked at "I will heal their backsliding" and "my anger has turned away". The first uses medical imagery for spiritual restoration, and the second personifies divine anger as something that can "turn away" from a person. Both are conventional but still clearly figurative.

instances.english_text: I will heal their affliction / I will heal their backsliding
vehicle: a sick or wounded condition that needs healing
ground: apostasy weakens and corrupts like a disease, and restoration is like healing
both involve a move from damaged to whole condition by an expert healer
conceptual mapping: spiritual infidelity ↔ disease; divine forgiveness ↔ healing
posture: portraying God as a healer rather than only a judge
instances.explanation: The Lord describes Israel’s waywardness as something to be "healed," using medical imagery for the process of forgiveness and spiritual restoration.

instances.english_text: For My anger has turned away from him
target: the cessation of God’s punitive wrath toward Israel
change in God’s stance from opposition to favor
vehicle: anger (lit. "my nose") turning back or away like a person changing direction
an attacking force or hostile face that turns aside
ground: when anger turns away, the threat is removed, like an attacker withdrawing
both involve a shift in orientation from confrontation to non-confrontation
conceptual mapping: emotional stance ↔ spatial orientation
posture: announcing the end of divine hostility
reassuring the audience of renewed favor
instances.explanation: God’s "anger" is personified as something that can turn away from someone, depicting the end of judgment as the withdrawal of a hostile presence.

deliberation: I noted three explicit similes marked by כ-: God "like dew" to Israel, Israel "blossom like the lily," and Israel "strike root like Lebanon." These use agricultural and botanical imagery to portray divine blessing, beauty, and stability.

instances.english_text: I will be to Israel like dew
vehicle: dew that falls gently on plants in a dry climate
quiet, regular moisture that sustains growth
ground: both dew and divine favor provide gentle, essential refreshment leading to life and growth
image of unobtrusive yet vital nourishment
conceptual mapping: dew ↔ God’s sustaining grace
posture: emphasis on gentleness rather than harshness
instances.explanation: God compares himself to dew, highlighting the quiet, steady, life-sustaining quality of his restorative presence toward Israel.

instances.english_text: He shall blossom like the lily
vehicle: a flower’s fresh and visible bloom
ground: both blooming flowers and renewed Israel display visible beauty and life after a dormant or damaged period
emphasis on freshness and aesthetic appeal
conceptual mapping: floral blossoming ↔ national/spiritual flourishing
instances.explanation: Israel is likened to a lily in bloom, picturing the community’s renewed life and beauty after repentance and healing.

instances.english_text: He shall strike root like a Lebanon tree
target: Israel’s stability and deep-rootedness after restoration
firmness and enduring strength of the nation
vehicle: trees of Lebanon (especially cedars) with deep, strong roots
ground: cedars of Lebanon are renowned for strength and permanence; a deeply rooted tree resists storms
similarly, a restored Israel will be stable and enduring
conceptual mapping: strong tree roots ↔ national durability
posture: countering previous images of uprooting and judgment
instances.explanation: Lebanon (its famous trees) serves as the comparison point for Israel’s renewed rootedness, depicting the nation as firmly established like a mighty cedar.

deliberation: I observed a continued arboreal imagery: shoots going forth, beauty like an olive tree, fragrance like Lebanon. The first treats Israel as a tree whose new growth spreads; the next two are explicit similes of splendor and aroma drawn from olive and Lebanon’s forests.

instances.english_text: His boughs/shoots shall spread out
target: the expansion and vitality of restored Israel (people, influence, descendants)
growth in numbers, influence, and blessing
vehicle: young shoots of a tree growing and extending outward
vigorous new branches spreading from a trunk
ground: both spreading shoots and national revival involve increase and outward extension
image of organic, continual growth rather than sudden change
conceptual mapping: tree’s new growth ↔ community’s expansion
instances.explanation: Israel is depicted as a tree whose young shoots go forth, portraying the people’s renewed vigor and expanding life.

instances.english_text: His beauty shall be like the olive tree’s
target: the attractiveness or honor of restored Israel
vehicle: a dignified, valuable tree in the landscape
ground: both an olive tree and a restored nation are marked by enduring vitality and valued presence
emphasis on steady, fruitful attractiveness rather than fleeting glamour
conceptual mapping: attractive tree ↔ honored community
posture: reversal of previous shame and disfigurement
instances.explanation: Israel’s renewed honor is compared to the beauty of an olive tree, a symbol of enduring, fruitful attractiveness.

instances.english_text: His fragrance like that of Lebanon
target: the pleasing effect and reputation of Israel
the community’s attractive presence and influence
vehicle: the fragrance of Lebanon’s forests (cedars, etc.)
ground: a fragrant forest gives pleasure to those near it; a restored Israel will be similarly pleasing to others (and to God)
both evoke delight and attraction rather than repulsion
conceptual mapping: pleasant scent ↔ favorable impact/reputation
posture: portraying Israel as a source of delight
countering earlier imagery of stench associated with judgment
instances.explanation: By likening Israel’s "fragrance" to that of Lebanon, the text uses the well-known aroma of Lebanon’s woods as a simile for the community’s renewed, pleasing reputation.

deliberation: I noted continuing tree imagery: those who sit in his shade, blossoming like the vine, remembrance like the wine of Lebanon. "Sitting in shade" metaphorically conveys protection and benefit; the latter two are explicit similes linking flourishing and renown to vineyard and wine imagery.

instances.english_text: They who sit in his shade shall return
target: those under the protection and beneficent influence of the restored Israel (or of God pictured as the tree’s owner)
vehicle: people sitting in the shade of a large tree
resting securely under protective cover from heat
ground: both shade-dwellers and protected people experience relief, security, and refreshment
shade shelters from oppressive heat as God’s favor shelters from harm
conceptual mapping: tree’s shade ↔ protective care
posture: depicting restored community as a place of refuge
encouraging trust in the renewed order
instances.explanation: Those who benefit from Israel’s restoration are pictured as people sitting in the shade of a tree, an image of protection and refreshment.

instances.english_text: They shall blossom like the vine
target: the community’s renewed fruitfulness and joy
those sheltered under the restored order flourishing
vehicle: a grapevine blossoming and bearing fruit
ground: both a flourishing vine and a restored people show evident, fruitful growth
image of abundance and festal joy associated with vineyards
conceptual mapping: vine’s blossoming ↔ communal prosperity
instances.explanation: Those under this shade will flourish as a vine does, suggesting a life of abundance and joy comparable to a thriving vineyard.

instances.english_text: His memory/fame shall be like the wine of Lebanon
target: the lasting reputation and remembered character of the restored figure/community
vehicle: wine of Lebanon with its aroma and quality
ground: both fine wine and good reputation are long-remembered, cherished, and enjoyed
emphasis on pleasant, enduring impact
conceptual mapping: fine wine ↔ desirable renown
posture: affirmation of a positive, enduring legacy
contrasting former notoriety with future honor
instances.explanation: By comparing his remembrance to the wine of Lebanon, the text likens the community’s future reputation to a prized, enjoyable wine, emphasizing pleasant and enduring renown.

deliberation: I focused on God’s self-description: "I am like a verdant cypress" and "from me your fruit is found." The first is an explicit simile using an evergreen tree for God’s protective, life-giving character; the second uses "fruit" metaphorically for benefits/blessings that come from God.

instances.english_text: I am like a verdant cypress
target: God’s enduring vitality and sheltering role
vehicle: an evergreen providing shade and visual prominence
ground: both a verdant cypress and God are characterized by enduring life, stability, and the ability to provide shelter
image of constancy and protection
conceptual mapping: evergreen tree ↔ steadfast divine protector
posture: self-revelation of God as a life-giving refuge
instances.explanation: God likens himself to a flourishing cypress, emphasizing his constant, sheltering, and life-sustaining nature in contrast to lifeless idols.

instances.english_text: Your fruit is provided by Me / From Me your fruit is found
target: the benefits, prosperity, and moral/spiritual outcomes Israel experiences
all good results in Israel’s life
vehicle: visible, edible produce of a plant
ground: fruit is the natural outcome of a tree’s life; blessings and good deeds are the outcome of God’s enabling grace
both are dependent on a prior source for their existence
conceptual mapping: fruit ↔ results/blessings
posture: reorienting Israel to recognize God as the sole source of all good
undermining trust in idols or self-sufficiency
instances.explanation: The verse uses "fruit" as a metaphor for all beneficial outcomes in Israel’s life, attributing them to God as the true source, just as fruit comes from a tree.

deliberation: I examined the wisdom appeal and especially the expressions about "the paths/ways of YHWH" being straight, the righteous walking in them, and transgressors stumbling. This is a sustained path/walk metaphor: God’s will as a road, obedience as walking, and disobedience as stumbling. I treat the three clauses as distinct figurative instances within one conceptual field.

instances.english_text: For the paths/ways of GOD are smooth/straight
target: God’s moral will and covenantal directives
the divinely ordained pattern of life
vehicle: a roadway with no crookedness or obstacles
ground: straight paths are reliable and safe; God’s ways are morally right and trustworthy
both suggest predictability, integrity, and non-deviousness
conceptual mapping: moral order ↔ roadway geometry
posture: presenting divine instruction as inherently sound, not treacherous
instances.explanation: God’s "ways" are depicted as "straight" paths, a metaphor that portrays his moral will as a reliable, non-crooked road for life.

instances.english_text: The righteous can walk on them
target: the conduct and life-course of righteous people
vehicle: walking along a path or road
deliberate forward movement on a way
ground: just as a traveler progresses by walking a path, the righteous advance in life by following God’s ways
both involve steady, purposeful progression within a defined route
conceptual mapping: moral conduct ↔ walking
posture: encouraging adherence to God’s ways as practicable and livable
portraying righteousness as a journey rather than a momentary act
instances.explanation: The righteous are said to "walk" in God’s ways, using the act of traveling on a path as a metaphor for living in obedience.

instances.english_text: While sinners/transgressors stumble on them
target: the failure and downfall of those who rebel against God
spiritual and ethical collapse under God’s standards
vehicle: stumbling while walking along a path
tripping and falling due to inability or unwillingness to walk rightly
ground: transgressors trip over the very standards meant for good, like clumsy travelers stumbling on a road
both involve inability to navigate a path properly, resulting in harm
conceptual mapping: moral failure ↔ physical stumbling
posture: warning that resistance to God’s ways brings self-injury
highlighting the paradox that what is right becomes a stumbling block to the wicked
instances.explanation: The verse portrays rebels as stumbling on God’s paths, turning the road meant for secure walking into a site of their own fall, a metaphor for moral and spiritual ruin.
